title: Did modern humans break evolution? - Quora

response.answer_text: That depends on what you mean by “modern.” But evolution was “broken” the moment it included humans. Humans are in an entirely different—and higher—kingdom from all other creatures on Earth. We are unique in ways evolution cannot account for. I just addressed this issue in another answer. So I’m providing a link to that answer, as well as others where I’ve dealt with the supposed evolution of humans. Unfortunately, the same or similar questions will continue to be asked on Quora. And, somehow, millions of people are missing the solid answers I’ve posted. Yes, it’s a thankless job. No. Evolution isn't a mechanism or a thing, it's a description. You can't break a description. The number of mutations that take place with every generation is about the same as it was a thousand or a hundred thousand years ago, so even the mechanism is intact. More mutations surviving means more experiments so a faster rate of change. The only broken part is attitude, with a lot of fear by what could be called older models that newer upgrades could replace them.

No. The presumption is that technology (particularly medicine) makes us no longer subject to natural selection. That is not true. Natural selection still works. What really slows down natural selection is our population. But that happens to any and every very large population. It’s part of evolution, not breaking it. There are 7.5 billion humans. Large populations cannot change very fast (in terms of generations). It simply takes too many generations for a new trait to spread so that everyone has it (fixed). With our generation time of 25 years, we are looking at over 175 billion years before a new trait could become fixed. We’ve seen this before in the fossil record. It’s called “stasis”. Humans are in stasis. Not because of our technology, but simply because of the huge number of people.

You seem to think that evolution is a process. No! It is the result of what happens over hundreds of thousands of years, given minuscule organic changes due to subtle mutations and dying off of lines of species that are not quite as good at surviving as other lines. It’s been going on for hundreds of millions of years. We have sort of put a crimp in evolution because we work very hard to make it possible for the disabled to survive, have normal lives and procreate. The survival of the fittest no longer applies nearly as much as it used to. Evolution will, however, continue to happen. We just don’t have a clue how it is going to occur and when. Not overly long, extremely readable and clear.

Did modern humans break evolution? Biological “Darwinian” evolution is still trucking away - humans have not changed that What we have done is added some additional pathways Cultural Evolution - by making improvements outside of genetics that can be changed and spread much faster we have introduced a new form of evolution that is hundreds of thousands of times faster Directed Evolution - starting with the development of food plants we have used evolution with humans acting as the selecting mechanism to direct the evolution of animals and plants Intelligent Design - we are starting to be able to actually design changes to animals and plants So not “broken” - but definitely altered

No. This is like asking if humans “broke” gravity when the Wright brothers developed heavier than air powered flight. You can’t “break” evolution by natural selection any more than you can “break” gravity. Evolution by natural selection will occur any time there is heritability (check), variation (check), and limited resources (check).

Do you mean that perhaps the human race has reached its pinnacle and cannot evolve further? History attests that once established, nature and the DNA work to ensure the stability of a species. Thus Gorillas will only ever be Gorillas and so on. Science and the fossil record attest that macro-evolution cannot and has not occurred. No new life forms have ever developed from another. Speciation has been restricted to life’s families, the dog, the cat and so forth. The human race is specifically excluded from speciation. We are a unique family and not able to cross breed with any other species. Our DNA ensures we will only ever be human beings and always able to interbreed with any other nationality. Chinese can breed with Hottentots, Siberians with Sudanese and all around the world. This won’t change.

We sort of changed the playing field with the introduction of technology. Instead of evolving to solve problems, we build technology to do so. We’re also starting to have the ability to change ourselves without the need of natural evolution. It doesn’t change what evolution is or how it works, and we’ll still evolve, it just represents a huge change on Earth, which will have enormous consequences in many ways, for everything on Earth. It’s like a phase shift. So far it has been absolutely disastrous for life on Earth, but not a lot of time has passed yet, so maybe it won’t continue this way. Or maybe it will.
